summary: There is a "desperate need" for housing for former prison leavers in Wales, a charity has said.
A man has been charged in connection with the seizure of firearms and ammunition in Edinburgh.
A judge has denied bail to four people accused of beating a black man and forcing him to drink toilet water in a Facebook Live video.
West Bromwich Albion have appointed Steve Evans as their new director of football following his departure from Reading.
The pancreas can be regenerated on a diet similar to a vegan diet, US scientists say.
The merger of the world's two biggest eyewear manufacturers, Essilor and Luxottica, is causing a lot of debate in the industry.
British Cycling's World Class Programme has been described as a "disaster" by three-time world champion Lizzie Houvenaghel.
It's not every day you get to meet the man who took over a comedy club and turned it into a multimillion dollar business.
When the regulator Ofcom announced last week that it would not be separating BT from its parent company, shares in the company soared.
Celtic manager Brendan Rodgers is relishing his first visit to Hampden Park as he prepares for Saturday's Scottish Cup semi-final against Rangers.
Queen's University in Belfast is to cut the number of student places by 1,010 over the next three years.
A hospital trust has apologised after 850 appointment letters were sent out with the wrong patient information.
The shadow foreign secretary has said Labour is "trying to get a compromise" with the government over the Brexit bill.
Torquay United manager Kevin Nicholson says he will not be getting any money from the sale of Kane O'Kane to Bournemouth.
An inquest into the death of a man whose body was found in the Menai Strait has heard he had been visited by a police officer while in hospital.
Sheffield Wednesday have signed Leicester City striker David Taylor-Fletcher on loan until the end of the season.
A former Nasa chief scientist has said it would be "an enormous disservice" to make climate change data unavailable under a Trump administration.
The Specials drummer John "Brad" Bradbury has died at the age of 69.
Former world number one Tiger Woods missed the cut at the Farmers Insurance Open as England's Justin Rose took a one-shot lead into the final round.
Former England striker Carlton Cole says he will not rush back to full fitness after having a kidney transplant.
Pakistan has lifted its ban on YouTube, four years after it was banned over a blasphemous video.
Leicester Tigers scrum-half Jamie Benjamin will miss the rest of the season with a knee injury.
Welsh cyclist Owain Doull said it felt like "a dream" as he won his third Olympic gold medal in Rio.
Floods in the western Indian state of Gujarat have killed more than 100 people and left thousands homeless, officials say.
It is believed to be the first wedding to be held on skis.
Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) has been fined $100m (£60m) by Hong Kong regulators for falsifying trading records.
The Baftas are over and it's time for the big winners to be revealed.
It has been a difficult year for Andy Murray.
Police in South Africa have arrested two men in connection with the fatal shooting of a local rapper on Saturday.
A man has been arrested on suspicion of attempted murder after a shot was fired near a Merseyside primary school.
Britain's Jessica Ennis-Hill remains on course to qualify for the Rio Olympics after the second day of the Hypo-Meeting in Gotzis, Germany.
More than 100 staff at the Manor team have been told they will be made redundant after the team went into administration.
The number of candidates standing in the Northern Ireland Assembly election has risen to 228.
What should you do if the pound falls against the US dollar before your trip to New York?
A teenager from New Zealand has been crowned the UK's Alternative Model of the Year.
Hundreds of people have signed a petition against plans to move a statue commemorating the Falklands War.
A British man has appeared in court charged with breaching a terror control order, the BBC has learned.
Sussex have appointed ex-wicketkeeper-batsman Chris Anyon as their new head coach of the women's side.
League One side Bury have signed midfielder Jordan Brown on a one-month loan deal from Championship side Sunderland.
Fairytales have long been a source of controversy, with many of the more recent adaptations updating the story for the 21st Century.
The Eurovision Song Contest took place in Kiev on Sunday, with countries from around the world taking part.
When The Beatles played their first gig in Liverpool's Cavern Club in 1963, it was the start of a career that would last more than 30 years.
South Africa's government has proposed a minimum wage of 12,000 rand ($1,200; £1,000) a year.
The death of Ethiopia's long-serving Prime Minister Meles Zenawi has sent shockwaves through the Horn of Africa.
Azhar Ali hit a half-century for Pakistan before rain washed out the second day of the second Test against Australia.
The Scottish Greens have lost the Leith Walk seat on Edinburgh City Council to Scottish Labour.
Russia has accused the US of being "irrational" for refusing to co-operate with its bombing campaign in Syria.
Scarlets have signed Wales Under-20 internationals Rhys Hughes and Rhys Evans.
US President Barack Obama is stepping down after eight years in the White House, and his successor, Donald Trump, has vowed to "reset" relations with Russia.
Labour is proposing to scrap university tuition fees in England.
Fire crews have finished their work at the scene of the Shoreham Air Show crash.
The US director of national intelligence has said he has never been directed to do anything "illegal, immoral, unethical or inappropriate" by the president.
The White House has confirmed that President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama attended a party in New York.

Mental health is one of the biggest challenges facing the world today.
To Kill a Mockingbird author Harper Lee has agreed to publish a second book after a state investigation found she was capable of consent.
The US has suspended its participation in talks with Russia aimed at ending the conflict in Syria.
Sadiq Khan has been elected as the first Muslim mayor of London.
A vicar has been appointed after a video in which children sang an advert for a new vicar went viral.
Manchester City midfielder Kevin de Bruyne will miss the rest of the season after injuring his ankle in the 2-2 draw with Everton.
A man who set fire to a train in the Swiss city of St Gallen, injuring six people, has died, police say.
Police are hunting for a "reckless" drone operator after a plane was nearly hit by the unmanned aircraft.
A seal that became tangled in netting on a beach in Aberdeenshire has been released back into the sea.
A collection of letters and manuscripts belonging to one of Scotland's most famous writers has been made public for the first time.
Mark Roache has been elected as the new general secretary of the GMB union.
As Laura Mvula prepares to perform on Later... with Jools Holland, she tells the BBC why she's "terrified" of live TV.
Newcastle United midfielder Jonas Gutierrez says he has been "born again" since being diagnosed with testicular cancer.
Exeter City have announced their first annual profit in more than a decade.
Paralympic athlete Abdullah Hayayei has died after a throwing cage collapsed on his head.
The Scottish Chambers of Commerce has issued a warning about the outlook for the economy in 2017.
An inquiry into undercover policing in England and Wales will "expose both creditable and discreditable conduct", Lord Justice Pitchford has said.
New Zealand reached the World Cup final for the fourth time in five years with a hard-fought victory over South Africa at Twickenham.
The National Trust is using radar to help improve the condition of the world's tallest obelisk.
Shares in Inditex, the owner of Zara and Massimo Dutti, have jumped more than 10% after the firm reported a rise in sales and profits.
When Lady Gaga takes to the stage at the Super Bowl in Houston, Texas on Sunday, she will be performing one of the most anticipated shows in the history of the event.
A woman who was sexually abused by an Asian gang in Rochdale has said she is still being approached by men in the town.
A department store in Birmingham has been forced to close for the second day after a water main burst.
An apparent bot attack has been detected on a US government website where people can comment on proposed changes to net neutrality.
Sale Sharks director of rugby Les Cotton says the club need to "rebuild" if they are to compete at the top level.
Moana has topped the US box office on its opening weekend, despite criticism of its depiction of Polynesian culture.
British number one Johanna Konta reached the quarter-finals of the Nottingham Open with a straight-set win over Madison Brengle.
Two men have been taken to hospital after being attacked by a group of men in Londonderry.
German scientists believe they have found the source of the Ebola outbreak in Guinea that killed seven-year-old Emile Diallo.
Former world number one Stuart Bingham says he could return to the World Championship if his wife gives birth to their third child.
A section of the pier which collapsed on to the seafront at Swansea Bay is to be demolished, the council has said.
A campaign group has launched a legal challenge against the University of Oxford's controversial tower blocks.
The head of a school trust has written to parents warning of "unthinkable" decisions it could have to make over funding.

Police investigating the discovery of a human skull on a motorway have said further skeletal remains have been found.
Colombia's Omar Martinez lost to Kazakhstan's Islam Dusmatov in the Olympic men's flyweight final in Rio.
University staff in England are to stage a one-day strike on Wednesday in a dispute over pay.
The Scottish government is to investigate East Dunbartonshire Council's plans to close a primary school.
Former Japan striker Kazuyoshi Miura has signed a new contract with Japanese side Vegalta Sendai.
Violence has broken out in Indian-administered Kashmir on the first anniversary of the killing of a militant leader.

Sale Sharks forward Tom Easter will leave the Premiership club at the end of the season to become a teacher.
Families of patients who died at a troubled mental health unit have said they are still waiting for answers.
A 35-year-old man has been jailed for punching and kicking two men in County Londonderry.
Two-time Olympic gold medallist Hope Solo has been suspended for two matches by the United States Women after being arrested on suspicion of drink-driving.
A lawyer at a leading law firm has admitted conspiracy to supply cocaine.
Police in Scotland are to begin using Tasers against suspects on the rail network.
A Grangemouth-based water pumping station manufacturer is to create 80 new jobs after securing funding from UK Steel Scotland (UKSE).

A man has been charged with the murder of his partner in south London.
Prostate cancer is one of the world's most neglected cancers.
Christian Wade scored a hat-trick of tries as Wasps beat Worcester Warriors to boost their Premiership play-off hopes.
A French woman has been killed in the Tunisian attack on the Bardo museum, which left at least 39 people dead, officials say.
Newly released images show how Islamic State (IS) militants have destroyed Mosul airport in a bid to prevent Iraqi forces from using it as a logistical base.
The main railway line between London and Reading will be closed for more than a week over the Easter weekend, Network Rail has said.
An oil and gas company has been granted a permit by Natural Resources Wales for exploratory drilling in Gwynedd.
Online retailer Amazon has changed the way it records sales in Europe in a bid to reduce its tax bill.
The chief medical officer for England has called on junior doctors not to go on strike in their long-running dispute with the NHS.
Oxford United midfielder Callum Kenny has signed a new one-year contract with the League One club.
A Dorset college has been awarded a £3.5m grant from the Department for Education to refurbish its buildings.
The Football Association's chairman is to meet the family of Jeff Astle to discuss head injuries and concussions.
The world's richest people have an average net worth of $50m (Â£40m), according to a leading financial expert.
Sale Sharks have extended the contracts of teenage forwards Tom and Ben Smith until the end of the 2017-18 season.
Police have released a CCTV image of a man they want to speak to in connection with a serious assault in Aberdeen.
The US has accused Egypt and other Arab countries of setting "unrealistic and unworkable conditions" for talks on nuclear disarmament.
Plans to devolve control over fracking in Wales remain on hold, the Welsh government has said.
World heavyweight champion Tyson Fury has been described as "an idiot" and "an all-action man".

More than 100 paintings and drawings by a World War One veteran have gone on display in his hometown.
Scott Brown's decision to retire at the end of last season was "clearly the wrong decision", according to former Scotland boss Neil Lennon.
A buzzard has been rescued after becoming stuck in a fence in County Durham.

Raith Rovers have signed former Kilmarnock midfielder Callum Johnston for an undisclosed fee.

"Did you set this up, BBC Radio Manchester?"
